fields.descriptive_line: Portrait miniature of an unknown man, watercolour on vellum, painted by Nicholas Dixon, 1665-1670.
fields.physical_description:
Portrait of a man, half-length, turned slightly to right and looking to front, wearing a neckcloth and armour, his hair about his shoulders.  Features hatched in brown and sanguine with some blue-grey shading and with touches of red in the lips; blue, black and touches of ochre with white highlights in the eyes; on a pale carnation ground; hair in long strokes of black with pale grey over a brown wash; collar modelled in greys over a white wash; armour in grey washes, modelled in dark grey and dark brown with white for the lights; the rivets in ochre with gold highlights; background to the left a solid dark brown wash and to the right a sky of blue washes with white and a touch of orange for the sunset; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. 

<u>Frame:</u> Seventeenth-century oval gold locket with convex back, the originally straight sides, with a single narrow channel, now much altered; the original front now missing; an over-size flat bevelled glass fitted to the front by pushing the upper part of the sides out to form a bezel; a hanger of D-section soldered to what was originally the bottom of the locket, with a short tail for reinforcement, and with two separate diminishing spirals of five turns in flat wire. The original top of the locket still bears finely engraved scroll-and-line ornament and marks of the filed-off hanger. The locket packed out with cut playing cards.
fields.title: An Unknown Man
fields.materials_techniques: Watercolour on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book
fields.bibliography: Murdoch, John. Seventeenth-century English Miniatures in the collection of the Victoria and Albert Museum. London: The Stationery Office, 1997. Cat. 155, pp. 264-265. Full citation: “Unknown Man” 1665-70 Evans 34 Oval 48 x 40 mm Features hatched in brown and sanguine with some blue-grey shading and with touches of red in the lips; blue, black and touches of ochre with white highlights in the eyes; on a pale carnation ground; hair in long strokes of black with pale grey over a brown wash; collar modelled in greys over a white wash; armour in grey washes, modelled in dark grey and dark brown with white for the lights; the rivets in ochre with gold highlights; background to the left a solid dark brown wash and to the right a sky of blue washes with white and a touch of orange for the sunset; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. Condition: Some minor rubs, but mainly excellent. Signed: Lower right, in gold: ND (see B in Appendix 2). Frame: Seventeenth-century oval gold locket with convex back, the originally straight sides, with a single narrow channel, now much altered; the original front now missing; an over-size flat bevelled glass fitted to the front by pushing the upper part of the sides out to form a bezel; a hanger of D-section soldered to what was originally the bottom of the locket, with a short tail for reinforcement, and with two separate diminishing spirals of five turns in flat wire. The original top of the locket still bears finely engraved scroll-and-line ornament and marks of the filed-off hanger. The locket packed out with cut playing cards. Provenance:Acquired by the Hon. F H A Wallop from an unrecorded source, and lent to the Museum 1927-49; the ownership transferred to Alan Evans in 1933 and by him bequeathed to the National Gallery, 1974; placed on indeterminate loan at the V&A. (See Appendix 3.) Exhibited: RA 1934, no. 957. Literature: Long 1929, p.128 ('an excellent Signed miniature of a man in armour'); Foskett 1979, p. 130, fig. 27a (dated c.1663); Summary Catalogue, 1981, p. 16 (as Duke of Albemarle); Murdoch 1981 p. 154, fig. 164 (as Unknown Man, c.1660). The miniature was identified by Wallop as a portrait of the 1st Duke of Albemarle (1608-1670), whose pre-Restoration portraiture is an uncertain subject. Long was sceptical and responded more favourably to a suggestion from Allan Fea that the sitter was Colonel John Lane, copied from a Cooper miniature that was reproduced in a book called The Flight of the King. (1) Neither suggestion seems satisfactory. Colonel Lane of Bentley Hall was the brother of the famous Jane Lane who helped Charles II to escape from the Battle of Worcester in September 1651. She rode pillion behind him through the Parliamentary lines near Stratford-upon-Avon and conducted him eventually in safety to Dorset. Her brother would have been a typical candidate in the nineteenth century for the optimistic identification of anonymous sitters. The supposed Cooper original is no longer extant. As for Albemarle, the standard images are the two Coopers of c.1660, the 'sketch' at Windsor, without the Garter ribbon conferred on him in 1660, (2) and the finished portrait with the Garter in the Buccleuch Collection; (3) the Lely in the 'Flagmen' series of c.1665; (4) and the miniature derivative, Anon., Cat. No.198. Judging by the sitter's apparent age, this miniature would have to be considerably earlier than any of these images, but to be by Dixon it cannot be earlier. Dixon must have been born c.1645, and the miniature, as a Signed and already accomplished work, cannot plausibly be dated before 1660, and preferably even later. 1 1897; MS note by Fea preserved in Evans Loan Book and transcribed in the Chrisrie's valuation of 1969, both Department of Prints, Drawings and Paintings. 2 Foskett 1974, fig. 67. 3 Kennedy 1917, pl. XXXII. 4 National Maritime Museum; copy NPG; Piper 1963, pl. 8f."
fields.credit: Alan Evans Bequest, given by the National Gallery
fields.history_note: <u>Provenance:</u> Acquired by the Hon. F H A Wallop from an unrecorded source, and lent to the Museum 1927-49; the ownership transferred to Alan Evans in 1933 and by him bequeathed to the National Gallery, 1974; placed on indeterminate loan at the V&A. (See Appendix 3.)
